title: Rodri and Zinchenko injuries add to Guardiola’s injury headaches at Man City
text:
Rodri limped out of the Champions League clash with Atalanta (Picture: AFP via Getty Images)

Oleksandr Zinchenko and Rodri are both set for a number of weeks on the sidelines, leaving Manchester City manager Pep Guardiola with serious injury problems in defence.

Zinchenko has been forced to undergo knee surgery, which has been described as minor, but is likely to be out for six weeks and not be available until December.

Rodri was forced off in the Champions League tie with Atalanta on Tuesday night with a hamstring problem, and that will keep the Spaniard out for around a month.

Guardiola said of Zinchenko’s injury: ‘He had a contact with a knee. He felt something in the bone and has to stop. He had something to clean up the knee. It was not a big issue. Five or six weeks.’

Adding on Rodri’s situation: ‘They told me after the [November] international break maybe he will be ready again.’

This would see Rodri come back for Man City’s home game against Chelsea on 23 November in the Premier League.

City have been struggling with injuries at the back, which forced Guardiola into playing Rodri at centre-back rather than his preferred position of central midfield.

However, they have been boosted by the returns to fitness of John Stones and Nicolas Otamendi, both of whom had been out through injury but are available for this weekend’s clash with Aston Villa.

Guardiola may choose to partner the returning pair in the middle of defence, or play one of them alongside Fernandinho who has also been filling in there.

At left-back, in Zinchenko’s absence, Benjamin Mendy or Joao Cancelo will fill the berth.

First choice centre back Aymeric Laporte remains out with a significant knee ligament injury and will not return until next year.
